 Drugs causing chronic intrahepatic
   cholestasis may produce a syndrome resembling primary biliary cirrhosis
   [36,41]. However, unlike primary biliary cirrhosis, serum
   antimitochondrial antibodies are usually not seen. Chronic cholestasis
   may evolve from acute drug-induced cholestasis. Most cases resolve with
   withdrawal of the offending [**Doctor Last Name **], but often require several months.
   However, some patients develop a vanishing bile duct syndrome and liver
   failure [67,68]. Drugs which have been reported to cause chronic
   intrahepatic cholestasis include amitriptyline, ampicillin,
   amoxicillin-clavulanate, carbamazepine, chlorpromazine, cyproheptadine,
   erythromycin estolate, haloperidol, imipramine, organic arsenicals,
   prochlorperazine, phenytoin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole,
   thiabendazole, tolbutamide, tetracycline, oral contraceptives, and
   anabolic steroids [69-71]. Those drugs implicated in chronic
   intrahepatic cholestasis and also ductopenia include carbamazepine,
   chlorpromazine, chlorpropamide, co-trimoxazole, haloperidol,
   thiabendazole, and tricyclic antidepressants.

   This is an 81 yo female with progressive painless jaundice over the
   past two weeks now presenting with hypotension and hypothermia likely
   representing sepsis.
   .
   # Septic Shock: Pt presenting with hypotension, tachycardia and
   leukocytosis of [**Numeric Identifier 5728**] with bandemia. Pressures improved with NS bolus
   though MAPs remain in the mid-50's. Possible infectious sources include
   urosepsis especially given urine cx positive for ESBL E.Coli which she
   was not receiving abx. She Would certainly also consider cholangitis
   given cholestatic picture, but too unstable for ERCP. CXR with patchy
   opacity in the left mid lung may indicate a possible PNA. Also with
   GPC's in blood, raising concern for line infection.
   - continue Meropenem, Flagyl and Vanco; has been afebrile since.
   - Goal MAPS >65; currently on 2 pressors, able to wean phenylephrine
   when pH corrected
   - Cont IVF boluses with NS for CVP 15-20
   - Blood and urine cxs- pending speciation of GPC in blood and GNR in
   urine (need to verify speciation and sensitivities of GNR)
   - daily surveillance cultures; now with GPC in [**2-28**] bottles, might
   consider pulling lines, but also concern for enterococcus; will await
   to see if coag negative or positive
   - repeat RUQ u/s without any ductal abnormalities; just fatty liver. CT
   with PO contrast with no acute abdominal abnormalities
   - Follow CXR
   - lactate trending down from 5.8-->3.4; due to infection vs.
   hypotension (had SBP's in 70's to 80's at some points on admission).
   -not candidate for MRCP b/c has pacer. Does not seem stable enough for
   ERCP and likely not any obstruction/intervention
   #Hypoxic Respiratory failure - Patient with remarkable effusion;
   currently on ARDs net; ? PNA as component
   -somewhat [**Last Name (LF) 8601**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] try to come down on midazolam and see response
    -continue AC vent
   - f/u BAL
   -hold on tap of effusions
   -ARDS vent with Vt 300cc.
   -ABG stable, corrected with amps of bicarb
   .
   # Metabolic Acidosis: Likely due to lactic acidosis evolving in septic
   patient. Lactate trending down now with broad spectrum antibiotics and
   adequate MAPs; received 6amps total of bicarb yesterday
   - cont trend ABG
   - cont trend lactate
   - continue to maintain pH 7.2.5 for ideal pressor action
   - empiric ABX
   .
   #  Elevated LFTs/Cholestasis: Given recent abd ct and u/s with normal
   appearing biliary tree, pancreas and liver seems more likely that these
   LFT abnormalities represent intrhepatic biliary obstruction or
   intrahepatic etiology (primary biliary cirrhosis, drug induced
   cholestasis, infiltrative process, neoplasm(cholangiocarcinoma,
   lymphoma). For drug induced cholestasis, possible culprits include
   levaquin (?), remeron (?)
   - appreciate liver recs
   - likely component of shock liver superimposed
   - d/c remeron
   -f/u hepatitis serologies, AMA, anti-Sm, [**Doctor First Name **]
   -continue to trend coags and DIC labs; correct coagulopathy if bleeding
   .
   # Acute renal failure- likely hemodynamic in origin
   -renally dose all meds
   -f/u urine lytes this AM (previously unable to produce urine)
   .
   # Bilateral Pleural Effusions: Left sided pleural effusion sig
   increased compared to last CXR from [**10-12**] at OSH. Per records these have
   been attributed to heart failure and have been transudative. Likely
   these effusions contributing to hypoxia.
   - cont to follow on CXR
   - thoracentesis if hypoxia worsens
   .
   #  Atrial Fibrillation: Pt currently in afib with RVR. Will hold off on
   giving nodal blocker at this time given tenous nature of BP. Per OSH
   records coumadin being held in anticipation of possible procedure.
   - hold metoprolol for now
   - hold coumadin given coagulopathy
   - attempt to rate control if BP stabilizes
   .
   # Diastolic Heart Failure: Holding BB and lasix given hemodynamic
   instability.
   .
   # ? GERD: cont PPI
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2181-10-13**] 07:42 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2181-10-13**] 08:35 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2181-10-13**] 09:43 PM

   DVT: None (too much bruising with boots)
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
   Disposition:ICU
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old female with a history of progressive painless jaundice, hypotension, and hypothermia. She is presenting with sepsis, severe metabolic acidosis, and respiratory failure. The patient has elevated liver function tests (LFTs) with cholestasis, acute renal failure, bilateral pleural effusions, atrial fibrillation, and potential diastolic heart failure. The patient is currently on multiple pressors, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and life support measures in the ICU with a DNR status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and leukocytosis with bandemia indicate sepsis. The positive urine culture for ESBL E. coli suggests a possible infectious source for the sepsis. Continuous monitoring and management of vital signs, fluid balance, and appropriate antibiotic therapy are essential.

2. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely due to lactic acidosis evolving in septic shock. Broad-spectrum antibiotics and adequate mean arterial pressure (MAPs) have been initiated, but close monitoring of ABG and lactate levels should continue.

3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may be attributed to bilateral pleural effusions and possible pneumonia. ARDSnet protocol is being followed, and further evaluation of BAL results is pending. Maintaining adequate oxygenation and ventilation is crucial

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old female presenting with progressive painless jaundice over the past two weeks. She is now experiencing hypotension and hypothermia, which are likely representing sepsis. The patient's condition has been complicated by several medical complications, including:

1. Sepsis with Organ Dysfunction: The patient is displaying signs of severe sepsis, as indicated by hypotension, tachycardia, leukocytosis, and bandemia. There are possible infectious sources, including urosepsis due to a positive urine culture for ESBL E. coli, and cholangitis. However, the patient is too unstable for an ERCP procedure.

2. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has metabolic acidosis likely due to lactic acidosis evolving in septic patients. Lactate levels are trending down with broad-spectrum antibiotics and adequate mean arterial pressure (MAP). The patient has received multiple amps of bicarbonate.

3. Elevated Liver Function Tests (LFTs)/Cholestasis: The patient's recent abdominal CT and ultrasound with normal appearing biliary tree suggest that the elevated LFT abnormalities represent intrahepatic biliary obstruction or intrahepatic etiology. Possible culprits for drug-induced cholestasis include Zosyn, Levaquin, and Remeron.

4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is likely hemodynamically compromised. Medications are being renally dosed

2. Respiratory Distress: The patient has a large pleural effusion and underlying pneumonia, causing hypoxia. She is being ventilated with assisted control ventilation (ACV) and will be transitioned to pressure support with a target tidal volume of 300 mL.

3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient is experiencing metabolic acidosis due to lactic acidosis, which is likely evolving in septic shock. Lactate levels are trending down with broad-spectrum antibiotics and adequate mean arterial pressure (MAPs).

4. Elevated Liver Function Tests (LFT): The patient's LFTs are elevated, possibly representing superimposed shock liver due to poor distal perfusion. Further evaluation with MRCP is recommended to rule out any obstruction.

5. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, likely of hemodynamic origin due to poor perfusion. Renal dosing of medications and consideration for

Coli, and Enterococcus in the urine, and is currently receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient is also experiencing shock, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, metabolic acidosis, atrial fibrillation, and diastolic heart failure. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is already showing signs of sepsis due to multiple infections. If not appropriately managed, sepsis can lead to organ failure and death.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and there is a risk of further deterioration, which may require intubation and mechanical ventilation.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and if not managed properly, it may progress to chronic renal failure.
4. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's lactic acid levels are elevated, indicating possible tissue hypoperfusion. If not corrected, this could lead to worsening acidosis and organ dysfunction.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is experiencing atrial fibrillation, which increases the risk of thromboembolic events if not adequately anticoagulated.

Summary of Progress Note:
- An 81-year-old female patient presents with progressive painless jaundice over two weeks.
- She is now experiencing hypotension and hypothermia, which may indicate sepsis.
- The patient has MRSA pneumonia and E. Coli and Enterococcus in her urine.
- She has been loaded with digoxin with a level this morning of 1.6.
- The patient is currently on a single pressor, phenylephrine, and is still waiting to discuss CVVH and goals of care with the family.
- Her vancomycin level this morning is 18.4.
- The patient is in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and has received a 500 cc bolus with no effect.
- Allergies include Keflex, Bactrim, and an unknown allergy.
- The last dose of antibiotics was metronidazole on 10/16/2181 at 08:00 AM, and meropenem on 10/17/2181 at 10:00 AM.
- Infusions include phenylephrine at 1 mcg/kg/min.
- Other ICU medications and changes to medical and family history are unchanged from admission.
- Review of systems is unchanged except as noted below.

TEXT:
Chief Complaint: 81 yof with a h/o atrial fibrillation diastolic heart
   failure, s/p cholecystectomy, and hospitalization for ESBL Klebsiella
   UTI ([**2181-9-26**]) transferred from [**Hospital1 608**] for work-up of LFT's. Per OSH
   records patient noted to be jaundiced while in rehab on [**2181-10-2**]. Her AP
   at that time was 568, AST 198, ALT 300 and TBili 5.58. She underwent
   abdominal u/s on [**10-7**] normal liver and bilateral pleural effusions. On
   [**10-11**] she had CT Abd at [**Hospital3 364**] Hosp as an outpt that showed
   normal liver, spleen, pancreas and bilateral pleural effusions. On
   admission to [**Hospital1 608**] her AP was 1206 and bili 15.9. Patient transferred
   to [**Hospital1 19**] for further work-up of her LFT abnormalities in sepsis with
   urine and lung sources.
   24 Hour Events:
   - patient in afib with RVR throughout yesterday - treated with 500cc
   bolus without effect - later improved with boluses of fentanyl
   - patient tachycardic to 140 with hypotension to 70/40 at 0300, given

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old female with a history of atrial fibrillation, diastolic heart failure, and previous hospitalization for Klebsiella UTI. She was transferred to the ICU for work-up of liver function abnormalities. On admission, she had significantly elevated liver enzymes and total bilirubin levels. Imaging studies showed normal liver, spleen, and pancreas with bilateral pleural effusions. The patient's condition has been complicated by sepsis from a urinary or lung source, intrahepatic cholestasis, shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, elevated liver function tests, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, and diffuse anasarca with weeping skin.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis from a urinary or lung source. This condition is life-threatening and requires immediate treatment with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.
2. Intrahepatic Cholestasis: The patient's liver function tests indicate intrahepatic cholestasis, which is a condition where bile cannot flow normally through the liver. This can lead to jaundice and other liver-related complications.
3. Shock: The patient has experienced shock, which is a critical condition characterized by inadequate blood flow to the organs. It can result in organ damage and failure if not treated promptly.
4. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory function is compromised, leading to hypoxia (low oxygen

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old female with a history of atrial fibrillation, diastolic heart failure, cholecystectomy, and previous hospitalization for an ESBL Klebsiella UTI. She was transferred from Hospital1 for work-up of elevated liver function tests (LFTs). The patient presented with jaundice, abnormal LFTs, and bilateral pleural effusions. Imaging studies showed normal liver, spleen, pancreas, and persistent pleural effusions. Her LFTs continued to worsen with significantly elevated AP, bilirubin, and LDH levels. She developed septic shock due to a suspected urinary or lung infection, leading to multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). The patient required mechanical ventilation, vasopressin support, and renal replacement therapy (CVVH). She also had acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), elevated liver enzymes, and intrahepatic cholestasis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic shock: The patient has been experiencing septic shock due to a suspected urinary or lung infection. This condition can lead to multiple organ dysfunction and potentially death if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's renal function is deteriorating, indicated by the elevated serum creatinine levels and urine output. Acute renal failure may require renal replacement therapy to remove waste products and maintain fluid balance.

The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and he has elevated lactate levels indicating metabolic acidosis. The patient has hypotension, impaired skin integrity, and is on mechanical ventilation.

3. Acute kidney injury: The worsening renal function and anuria indicate a risk of acute kidney injury.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The intrahepatic cholestasis and elevated liver enzymes may lead to hepatic encephalopathy.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's ongoing atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response can potentially worsen or lead to other arrhythmias.
6. Pressure ulcers: The patient's impaired skin integrity and diffuse anasarca put him at risk for

The patient is an 81-year-old male with intrahepatic cholestasis and sepsis from a urinary or lung source. He continues to have atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFIB) and worsening renal function. The patient is in continued septic shock requiring vasopressin support with MRSA pneumonia vs. urosepsis as the infective source.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock: The patient is experiencing septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition that occurs when an infection leads to dangerously low blood pressure. This can cause inadequate blood flow to vital organs.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has hypoxic respiratory failure due to bilateral large effusions and underlying MRSA pneumonia. This means that the lungs are not effectively exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide, leading to low oxygen levels in the blood.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, likely caused by poor perfusion. This is characterized by a sudden decrease in kidney function, leading to the accumulation of waste products and electrolyte imbalances in the body.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is in AFIB with RVR. AFIB is an irregular heart rhythm that can lead to poor blood flow and increase the risk of blood clots and stroke.
5. Liver Function Abnormalities: The patient has elevated liver function tests (LFTs) indicating liver dysfunction. This can be due to various causes such as

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

He was admitted with grossly abnormal liver function tests (LFTs) in the setting of sepsis from a urinary tract infection (UTI) and MRSA pneumonia, and is now anuric (not producing urine). 

The patient's current conditions include:
1. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count continues to drop, which is concerning for potential bleeding complications. Possible causes include synthetic dysfunction, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), or splenic sequestration.
2. Sepsis: The patient is still experiencing septic shock, likely due to MRSA pneumonia or a urinary source. He is being treated with antibiotics and vasopressin to maintain blood pressure.
3. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient has bilateral large effusions and underlying MRSA pneumonia, resulting in respiratory failure. Antibiotics are being continued, and the patient's fluid intake and output need to be carefully managed due to anuric renal failure.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level has risen to 4.1, indicating acute renal failure. Continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH or HD) is being considered, but the family is hesitant about long-term dialysis.

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure. He was admitted with grossly abnormal liver function tests in the setting of sepsis from a urinary tract infection (E.coli and Enterococcus) and MRSA pneumonia. The patient is now anuric, meaning he has no urine output. The family met with the healthcare team to discuss treatment options and the possibility of comfort measures only (CMO). Digoxin was increased to 0.125 mg, which resulted in a low heart rate response.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver function tests, atrial fibrillation, and skin issues. The patient's condition remains unstable, and he requires ongoing support with vasopressin and multiple medications for his various conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic Shock: The patient's ongoing requirement for vasopressor support indicates persistent septic shock. This can lead to further organ dysfunction and potentially death if not adequately managed.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying MRSA pneumonia and large effusions pose a significant risk for worsening respiratory failure. Aggressive management of his respiratory status is crucial.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's anuria and rising creatinine levels suggest acute renal failure, likely due to poor perfusion

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure. He was admitted with grossly abnormal liver function tests (LFTs) in the setting of sepsis from a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by E. coli and Enterococcus, as well as MRSA pneumonia. The patient is currently anuric (not producing urine).

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate in the low 100s, blood pressure of 107/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on supplemental oxygen. The patient's heart rhythm remains in atrial fibrillation.

The patient has been treated with various medications including vasopressin, fentanyl, and antibiotics such as meropenem, vancomycin, and daptomycin. The patient's fluid balance shows a net positive balance of 1,778 mL over the past 24 hours.

Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, low platelet count, elevated creatinine, liver enzymes, and bilirubin levels. Imaging studies show improving airspace opacities in the left mid and lower lung fields, possibly due to improving pneumonia, dense opacification in the right perihilar and retrocardiac area, and bilateral pleural effusions.

The patient's assessment and plan include ongoing septic shock requiring vasopressin

Based on the provided information, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of intrahepatic cholestasis and sepsis from a urinary or lung source. The patient also has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and renal failure.

The patient's current condition includes:

1. Shock: The patient is experiencing septic shock requiring vasopressin support. The source of infection could be either MRSA pneumonia or urosepsis.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient has bilateral large effusions and underlying MRSA pneumonia. Serial chest X-rays have not shown any improvement.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are rising, indicating acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to poor perfusion. Renal replacement therapy (CVVH or HD) is being considered, but the family is hesitant about long-term hemodialysis.

4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is dropping rapidly. Possible causes include synthetic dysfunction, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), splenic sequestration, or drug-induced thrombocytopenia.

5. Elevated Liver Function Tests (LFTs): The patient's AST/ALT levels are trending down, while alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and total bilirubin (TBili) remain constant. This suggests intrahepatic cholestasis or an obstructive

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient:

1. Shock: The patient is currently experiencing septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by poor blood flow and organ perfusion. The patient requires vasopressin support to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg.

2. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient has bilateral large effusions and underlying MRSA pneumonia. This combination may lead to difficulty in breathing and inadequate oxygenation. Continuous antibiotics and respiratory support will be necessary to manage this condition.

3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, indicating a decline in kidney function. This could be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) caused by poor perfusion. Continuous renal dosing of medications and consideration of renal replacement therapy (CVVH or HD) should be considered, taking into account the family's wishes not to pursue long-term dialysis.

4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has been dropping rapidly, indicating a potential risk of bleeding. This could be drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Close monitoring of platelets is essential, and consideration may be given to stopping meropenem or switching from vancomycin to daptomycin, although this poses challenges due to the ongoing septic shock physiology.

5. Elevated liver function tests (LFTs): AST/ALT levels

He was admitted with grossly abnormal liver function tests in the setting of sepsis from a urinary tract infection (E. coli and Enterococcus) and MRSA pneumonia. The patient is now anuric (not producing urine).

The patient's treatment options were discussed during a family meeting, including the possibility of comfort measures only (CMO). Digoxin was increased to 0.125 mg, and the patient's heart rate response is now in the low 100s.

The patient is currently receiving vasopressin at a rate of 2.4 units/hour. Other ICU medications include fentanyl, which was started on 10/23/2181 at 4:02 AM.

The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old individual with a history of atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure. The patient was admitted due to grossly abnormal liver function tests in the setting of sepsis from a urinary tract infection (E.coli and Enterococcus) and MRSA pneumonia. Currently, the patient is in anuric renal failure.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.8 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 99 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 116/60 to 132/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient is on vasopressin infusion and other ICU medications. 

The patient's physical examination reveals light crackles in the bilateral lungs, irregular heart rhythm with no murmurs, soft abdomen, diffuse anasarca, weeping skin, and wounds with deep tissue injury (WWP) and diabetes pedalis (DP) 2+. 

Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine, potassium, and liver enzymes. Imaging and microbiology reports are mentioned but not detailed in this summary.

The patient's assessment and plan include ongoing management of intrahepatic cholestasis and sepsis from urinary and/or lung sources, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, continued anuric renal failure,

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with intrahepatic cholestasis and sepsis from a urinary and/or lung source. He has been diagnosed with acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver function tests (LFT), atrial fibrillation, diastolic heart failure, and diffuse anasarca. The patient is currently in septic shock state requiring vasopressin support, and the possible sources of infection are MRSA pneumonia and urosepsis. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock: The patient continues to be in a septic shock state requiring vasopressin support. This indicates a potentially life-threatening condition that can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient has bilateral large effusions and underlying MRSA pneumonia. His respiratory status remains unchanged, indicating a potential risk of worsening respiratory failure.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has anuric renal failure with a rising creatinine level of 4.5. This suggests a decline in kidney function, which may require further intervention such as continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH/HD) or dialysis.

4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has been dropping initially but has stabilized recently. It is important to monitor the platelet levels closely, as thrombocytopenia can increase the risk of bleeding complications.

5. Elevated Liver

   with MRSA pneumonia vs. urosepsis as infective source.

   (Entrococcus and MRSA) - started on [**10-14**]

   and underlying MRSA pneumonia and unchanged disease demonstrated by
   serial CXR

   Cr, now 4.5

   - CVVH and HD considered, however not c/w longterm GOC per family
   # Thrombocytopenia: initially rapidly dropping platelet count with most
   recent level stabilized, likely representing drug induced
   thrombocytopenia.
   - continue to trend platelets
   - may consider pulling off Meropenum or  switching from Vancomycin to
   Daptomycin but difficult as patient still has septic shock physiology
   requiring pressors
   #  Elevated LFT
s: AST/ALT continue to trend down while AP/LDH and
   TBili continue to remain constant representing intrahepatic cholestasis
   or obstructive picture with now resolving component of shock liver.
   Liver suggested the next steps in investigating these abnormalities
   would include an MRCP to r/o obstruction or an transjugular liver
   biopsy.

 however patient has pacemaker

   increased dose to 0.125
    - improved rate control on high digoxin dose
 continue to titrate

   sloughing

   mattress

   electrolytes PRN, continue tube feeds

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure. He was admitted with grossly abnormal liver function tests (LFTs) in the setting of sepsis from a urinary tract infection (UTI) and MRSA pneumonia. The patient is currently in anuric renal failure and has been on vasopressin support. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 99 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 116/60 to 132/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient is on CPAP/PSV mode with a tidal volume of 426 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fractional inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient has diffuse anasarca, weeping skin, and significant risk of skin sloughing. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, high blood urea nitrogen (BUN), elevated creatinine, and abnormal liver enzymes. The patient's platelet count is also low.

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure. He was admitted with grossly abnormal liver function tests in the setting of sepsis from a urinary tract infection (E.coli and Enterococcus) and MRSA pneumonia. The patient is now in anuric renal failure.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 99 bpm, blood pressure of 116/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on endotracheal tube with CPAP/PSV ventilation. The patient is receiving vasopressin at a rate of 1.5 units/hour.

The patient's fluid balance shows a total input of 898 mL and a total output of 265 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 633 mL. The patient's weight is currently 82.3 kg, up from his admission weight of 63.6 kg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of white blood cells (18.7 K/uL), hemoglobin (9.5 g/dL), creatinine (4.5 mg/dL), blood urea nitrogen (102 mg/dL), and liver enzymes (ALT/AST: 143/156). The patient's platelet count is low at 73 K/uL. Other lab values include sodium (141 mg/d
